answers.author: Katie Johnston
answers.text:
Gregory,
I think the best examples in our area are public/non-profit partnerships, foundations for Public Schools (http://ffts.org/) and Parks (http://www.metroparksfoundation.org/). Both foundations work closely with government agencies to determine funding gaps while remaining separate organizations. 
After a quick search, I found several national resources for school foundations across the country. The School and Parks specific models could be of use for developing public/private partnerships to support and fund other services. These foundations may in part be successful because they support specific service areas.

answers.author: William Lutz
answers.text:
Greg, one thing that we did here in PIqua is we established a separate 501 (c) (3) non-profit corporation which is governed by an independent board of trustees.  This corporation gladly accepts donations and works with city staff to implement projects to have the donations pay for the improvements.  The corporation also has a strong record of leveraging those dollars by hitting up private foundations for more dollars.  It's worked well.
